chapters.chapterTitle: The Genealogy and Birth of Jesus Christ

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Matthew 1:1-25 aloud, focusing on the genealogy and birth narrative
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'the son of' (e.g., 'son of David', 'son of Abraham')
Pay attention to the emotional tension in Joseph's decision to divorce Mary quietly (v.19) and the angel's reassurance (v.20-21)
The phrase 'Immanuel' (v.23) is a key Hebrew term meaning 'God with us'

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: Summarize WHO is traced in the genealogy, WHAT happens at the birth of Jesus, WHERE and WHY this birth is significant for Jewish believers
tips: Include the genealogy from Abraham to Joseph (v.1-17)
Note the virgin birth (v.18-25) and the angel's message to Joseph (v.20-21)
Highlight the fulfillment of the prophecy (v.22-23) that the virgin will conceive and bear a son named Immanuel

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the genealogy (v.1-17), the virgin birth (v.18-20), or the angel's message (v.20-21)?
tips: The angel's message to Joseph: 'do not fear to take Mary as your wife' (v.20) shows God's direct intervention in a Jewish context
The name 'Jesus' (v.21) meaning 'God saves' ties the birth to the salvation of God's people
The phrase 'Immanuel' (v.23) resonates because it emphasizes God's presence in the midst of humanity

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Matthew trying to communicate to Jewish believers about Jesus through this genealogy and birth story?
tips: Matthew is establishing Jesus as the fulfillment of the Jewish promises (son of David and Abraham)
He emphasizes the virgin birth to show Jesus' divine origin and the fulfillment of Old Testament prophecies
The theme of Immanuel (God with us) addresses the Jewish expectation of a Messiah who would be present among them

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The genealogy's length? The virgin birth? Why Joseph is the legal father but not the biological one?
tips: The genealogy in Matthew 1:1-17 is a condensed version of the Jewish lineage to show Jesus' connection to David and Abraham; note the jumps (e.g., from Abraham to Isaac, then to Jacob, etc.)
The virgin birth (v.18-25) is a theological concept that Jesus was conceived by the Holy Spirit, which challenges cultural expectations of lineage
Joseph's role as the legal father (v.18-25) is a Jewish practice of naming the child after the husband, but the biological father is the Holy Spirit

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How does the theme of Immanuel (God with us) apply to your life this week?
tips: Consider a situation where you feel distant from God (like in a time of stress or uncertainty)
Pray for God's presence in your daily life, just as Immanuel was present in the birth of Jesus
Ask God to help you trust in His provision, as Joseph did when he was told by the angel

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray for God's presence (Immanuel) in your life and for faith to trust the virgin birth of Jesus.
tips: Thank God that He is with us (Immanuel) even when we don't see Him
Pray for courage to trust in God's plan, as Joseph did
Ask God to help you understand the divine nature of Jesus, the Son of God

chapters.chapterTitle: The Temptation and Beginning of Ministry

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Matthew 4:1-16 aloud, focusing on the dialogue between Jesus and the devil in verses 1-11 and the beginning of ministry in verses 12-16.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'It is written' (three times) in Jesus' responses to the devil's temptations
Pay attention to the phrase 'for the kingdom of heaven is at hand' (v.17) as a key declaration

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (Jesus) is tested, WHAT (the devil's three temptations), WHERE (the wilderness), and WHY (to prove obedience to God's Word and to begin His ministry).
tips: Include the three specific temptations and Jesus' responses with Scripture
Note that after the temptation, angels minister to Him (v.11) and then He begins preaching (v.17)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Jesus' response to the first temptation (v.4), the second temptation (v.6), the third temptation (v.10), or the beginning of ministry (v.17).
tips: The phrase 'Man shall not live by bread alone' (v.4) shows Jesus' focus on spiritual sustenance over physical hunger
The declaration 'the kingdom of heaven is at hand' (v.17) is a call to immediate repentance and response
Jesus' final response to the devil: 'Be gone, Satan!' (v.10) demonstrates His authority over the devil

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Matthew trying to communicate to Jewish believers about Jesus' identity and mission?
tips: Matthew wrote for Jewish believers to show that Jesus fulfills the Old Testament promises and defeats the devil with Scripture
The kingdom of heaven is now present through Jesus, and Jewish believers are called to follow Him (the call to discipleship)

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The 40-day fast, the devil's three temptations, and the phrase 'kingdom of heaven'?
tips: The 40-day fast was a period of testing and purification (like Moses in Exodus) but Jesus' fasting was to prepare for His public ministry
The devil's temptations exploit Jewish beliefs: turning stones to bread (physical need), the temple (holy place), and kingdoms of the world (political power)
The phrase 'kingdom of heaven' (Greek: basileia tes ouranou) refers to a spiritual kingdom that is now present through Jesus, not a political one

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: This week, identify one area where you are tempted to seek immediate physical or worldly satisfaction (like the devil's first temptation) and choose to trust God's provision through Scripture.
tips: Practice daily Scripture reading (e.g., Matthew 4:4, 6, 10) to resist temptation
When faced with a situation that feels like the devil's temptation, pray for God's provision and trust in His Word

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray about Jesus' victory over temptation and the call to follow Him.
tips: Thank God for Jesus' victory over the devil (so we don't have to face the same temptations)
Ask for strength to resist the devil's temptations in daily life
Pray for the courage to follow Jesus and to share the gospel (as He calls disciples to be 'fishers of men')

chapters.chapterTitle: The Sermon on the Mount: Beatitudes and the Law

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Matthew 5:1-20 aloud, paying attention to the flow from the Beatitudes to the salt and light metaphors and the fulfillment of the Law.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'blessed are' in verses 3-10
Pay attention to the contrast between the Law and the new righteousness in verses 17-20
Listen for the emotional shift from the Beatitudes to the call for heart righteousness

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (Jesus) is teaching, WHAT (the Beatitudes and the nature of true righteousness), WHERE (on a mountain in front of the crowds), and WHY (to reveal the kingdom of heaven through heart righteousness).
tips: Include the threefold movement: blessing the poor, the meek, and the persecuted
Note the contrast between external righteousness (scribes and Pharisees) and internal righteousness
Describe the salt and light metaphors as practical expressions of the kingdom

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the Beatitudes (v.3-10), the salt and light (v.13-14), or the call for heart righteousness (v.20)?
tips: The Beatitudes: 'Blessed are the poor in spirit' (v.3) challenges the worldly view of wealth and status
The salt and light metaphor (v.13-14) shows how believers are to influence the world without being corrupted
The statement about 'righteousness exceeding the scribes and Pharisees' (v.20) reveals the depth of heart transformation needed

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Matthew trying to communicate to Jewish believers about the nature of righteousness and the fulfillment of the Law?
tips: Matthew emphasizes that the Kingdom of Heaven is accessed through heart righteousness, not ritual observance
The Law is fulfilled by Christ's teaching, not abolished (v.17-20) - meaning the Law remains binding but now interpreted through Christ
This passage shows that true righteousness comes from the heart (like Christ's) rather than external compliance

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are confusing? The 'fulfillment' of the Law, the requirement for heart righteousness, or the severity of anger?
tips: The term 'fulfill' (v.17) means Christ satisfies the Law's demands through his life and death, so the Law remains valid but now with a new understanding
'Exceeding the scribes and Pharisees' (v.20) means having a righteousness that comes from the heart (like Christ's) rather than external rituals
Anger (v.21-22) is a sin because it shows a lack of love and control, which can lead to murder

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you live with heart righteousness this week? Focus on one area where you need to let go of external compliance to embrace true righteousness.
tips: Choose a situation where you are angry with someone and practice being meek (v.3-4)
Ask God to help you see your righteousness in terms of heart, not just actions
Pray for the grace to be 'poor in spirit' (v.3) when you feel proud

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray for the grace to live as salt and light in the world, embodying the heart righteousness of Christ.
tips: Thank God for the Beatitudes and the promise of the kingdom
Ask for the strength to be meek and humble when you are angry
Pray for the guidance to live righteously from the heart, not just the external

chapters.chapterTitle: The Sermon: Judging, Asking, and Building

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Matthew 7:1-28 aloud, focusing on the contrast between the speck and log (v.3-5), the threefold command (v.7-8), and the rock foundation (v.24-27).
tips: Notice the repetition of 'do not judge' (v.1)
Pay attention to the contrast in v.3-5: 'Why do you see the speck... but do not notice the log.'
Notice the threefold command in v.7-8: 'Ask, seek, knock'

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (Jesus) does WHAT (teaches), WHERE (in the temple or public space), and WHY (to avoid self-judgment and build on Christ).
tips: Include the parable of the speck and log (v.3-5)
Note the threefold command: 'Ask, seek, knock' (v.7-8)
Describe the narrow gate and rock foundation (v.24-27)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the speck/log contrast (v.3-5), the threefold command (v.7-8), or the rock foundation (v.24-27).
tips: The speck/log contrast is a powerful metaphor for self-centeredness and the need for humility
The threefold command shows God's responsiveness to the believer's need in practical ways
The rock foundation represents Christ as the only secure foundation for life

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Matthew trying to communicate to Jewish believers through this passage?
tips: Matthew wrote for Jewish believers to show that Jesus' teachings (the Sermon on the Mount) are the fulfillment of the Law and Prophets
The main point is that true discipleship requires humility, active faith (asking, seeking, knocking), and building on Christ (the rock) rather than on self
This passage addresses the Jewish context of self-righteousness and the need for Christ as the only foundation

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The speck/log contrast, the narrow gate, or the rock foundation?
tips: The speck/log contrast: This is a metaphor for self-righteousness and the tendency to criticize others without self-examination
The narrow gate: In Jewish context, gates were common metaphors for access to God; the 'narrow' implies the difficulty of true discipleship
The rock foundation: This points to Christ as the only foundation (as in 1 Corinthians 3:11), which may be challenging because it requires a radical shift from self-reliance

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: This week, practice one of the threefold commands (ask, seek, knock) in an area where you need God's help.
tips: Identify a specific area where you might be the 'log' (self-centered) and seek to remove it
Pray for the courage to ask God for help in a situation that feels difficult
Practice being humble by noticing the 'speck' in your own life before criticizing others

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for the power of asking, seeking, and knocking. Ask for humility to see the log in your own life and the courage to build on Christ.
tips: Thank God for providing the answer to your prayers
Pray for the humility to recognize your own sin (the log) and the need for Christ
Ask God to help you build your life on the rock (Christ) rather than on self

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Matthew 8:1-27 aloud, paying attention to the dialogue between Jesus and the leper (v.1-3), the centurion's request (v.4-13), and the storm scene (v.23-27).
tips: Notice the phrase 'I will; be clean' (v.3) - Jesus' immediate authority without condition
Pay attention to the centurion's humility: 'I am not worthy to have you come under my roof' (v.8)
The emotional shift in the storm: 'Why are you afraid, O you of little faith?' (v.26)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, summarize who Jesus healed, where it happened, and why He did it (using the 5W+H framework).
tips: Include the leper's cleansing (v.1-3) and the centurion's servant (v.4-13)
Note the storm scene (v.23-27) as a demonstration of authority
Mention the fulfillment of Isaiah 53:4 (v.17)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the leper's humility (v.1), the centurion's faith (v.8), or Jesus' calming of the storm (v.23-27)?
tips: The leper's request shows complete trust in Jesus' power (v.1)
The centurion's faith is rare in Israel (v.8) - he doesn't need Jesus to come, just a word
The storm scene demonstrates Jesus' authority over nature (v.23-27)

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Matthew trying to communicate to Jewish believers about Jesus' identity and authority through these miracles?
tips: Matthew emphasizes Jesus' authority as the fulfillment of Isaiah 53:4 (v.17)
The centurion's faith (v.8) shows that even non-Jews recognize Jesus' power
The storm calming (v.27) demonstrates that Jesus is God in action (the Son of God)

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The centurion's role, the phrase 'bore our diseases', and Jesus' sleep during the storm?
tips: The centurion was a Roman military officer (not Jewish) - his faith shows universal acceptance of Jesus
'Bore our diseases' refers to Jesus taking the sickness of humanity on Himself (as the atoning sacrifice) - from Isaiah 53:4
Jesus sleeps because He is in a state of divine rest (not human fatigue) - the storm is a test of His authority

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply Jesus' authority over healing and nature to a situation this week? (Example: When you feel sick, or when you face a storm of circumstances)
tips: Ask: 'Is there a 'leper' in my life that I need to be cleansed by Jesus?'
Practice faith like the centurion: 'What if I could just say the word (in faith) and have my problem resolved?'
When facing difficulties, remember Jesus calmed the storm - ask Him to calm your anxieties

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray for God's healing and authority in your life, as demonstrated by Jesus in Matthew 8.
tips: Thank God for cleansing you from sin and disease (like the leper)
Ask for faith like the centurion to trust in Jesus' word
Pray for courage to face life's storms (like the disciples) and trust Jesus to calm them

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Matthew 11:20-30 aloud, focusing on the dialogue between Jesus and John's disciples, the list of Christ's works, and the invitation to rest.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'the blind receive their sight' and the list of miracles (vv. 20-24)
Pay attention to the phrase 'blessed is the one who is not offended by me' (v. 20)
The contrast between John and the least in the kingdom (v. 29)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (Jesus and John's disciples) does WHAT (responds to John's question about his identity) in WHERE (the cities where Jesus was teaching) and WHY (to show the signs of the kingdom and invite the weary).
tips: Include John's question in prison (v. 20-21)
Note Jesus' response with the works of the kingdom (vv. 20-24)
Mention the invitation to the weary (vv. 28-30)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the list of Christ's works (vv. 20-24), the blessing of not being offended (v. 20), or the invitation to rest (v. 28)?
tips: The list of miracles shows Jesus' identity as the Messiah through His works
The phrase 'blessed is the one who is not offended by me' addresses the tension of Jesus' teachings
The contrast with John highlights the kingdom's priority

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Matthew trying to communicate to Jewish believers about the Messiah and the kingdom of heaven?
tips: Matthew was writing for Jewish believers to show Jesus as the fulfillment of the Law and Prophets
The passage emphasizes Jesus' identity as the Messiah through His works and the invitation to the kingdom
The contrast with John shows that even the greatest among Jews are not as great as the least in the kingdom

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: Identify 2-3 confusing elements in this passage and explain their meaning.
tips: The phrase 'least in the kingdom' refers to humility and service, not the size of the person
'The dead are raised up' is a sign of the kingdom's power, not a literal resurrection of the dead (as in the resurrection of Christ)
'Yoke' refers to a shared burden, so 'easy yoke' means Jesus shares the burden with us

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply Jesus' invitation to rest in your current life?
tips: Consider an area where you feel burdened and need rest
Think about taking Jesus' yoke upon you - what does that mean for your current stress?
How can you practice finding rest in Him this week?

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray: Thank God for the invitation to rest and ask for the strength to take His yoke.
tips: Thank God for Jesus as the rest for weary souls
Pray for the courage to follow Jesus' yoke even when it's hard
Ask for the grace to be the 'least' in the kingdom and find rest

chapters.chapterTitle: John Beheaded and Jesus Feeds Five Thousand

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Matthew 14:1-33 aloud, paying attention to the dialogue between Herod and his servants in verses 1-11, and the emotional tone of Jesus' compassion in verses 14-21.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'John the Baptist' (v.1, v.3) and the phrase 'He has been raised from the dead' (v.3)
Pay attention to the contrast between Herod's fear (v.5) and his reckless request for John's head (v.7)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is involved, WHAT happens, WHERE it occurs, and WHY Jesus leaves the crowd in the desolate place.
tips: Include the key events: Herod's imprisonment of John, Herodias' request for John's head, Jesus' withdrawal to a desolate place, and the feeding of the five thousand
Note that Jesus' compassion leads him to heal the sick and feed the crowd with a few loaves and fish
Mention the walking on water as a parallel to the feeding miracle

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: John's martyrdom (v.1-12), Jesus' compassion (v.14-21), or the feeding miracle (v.19-21).
tips: The phrase 'It is not lawful for you to have her' (v.3) shows John's moral authority and the danger of Herod's actions
Jesus' compassion: 'He had compassion on them and healed their sick' (v.14) reveals His heart for the marginalized
The feeding miracle: 'They all ate and were satisfied' (v.20) demonstrates God's provision for the many

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Matthew trying to communicate to Jewish believers about Jesus' identity and mission through this passage?
tips: Matthew emphasizes Jesus as the true fulfillment of the Law and the prophets, especially through His compassion and power
The passage shows Jesus' authority over sin (John's death) and His provision for the people (feeding the multitudes)
The walking on water (v.26) illustrates Jesus' divine power and the need for faith in Him

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The role of Herodias, the reason for the feeding miracle, and the walking on water.
tips: Herodias' role: She was Herod's wife, but Herod's marriage was a political arrangement; her request for John's head was a political and personal conflict
The feeding miracle: It occurs after Jesus has already been tested by Herod's actions, showing His provision in the midst of chaos
Walking on water: This is a sign of Jesus' divine authority over nature, but it also challenges the disciples' faith (v.28)

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you practice the compassion of Jesus in feeding the multitudes this week?
tips: Consider an area where you are 'the crowd' needing provision: a friend, a family member, or a community group
Think about what small acts of provision you can do, like sharing resources or time, just as Jesus did with the five loaves and two fish
Ask God to help you be a source of compassion for others, even when it seems impossible

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His compassion and provision, and ask for the courage to trust Him in difficult situations.
tips: Thank God for the feeding of the multitudes as a sign of His provision for all who trust Him
Pray for the strength to face the challenges of life without becoming like Herod (who was influenced by his wife's desires)
Ask God to help you walk on water in your faith, trusting Him when the waters are deep

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Matthew 15:1-22 aloud, paying attention to the dialogue between the Pharisees and Jesus in verses 2-4 and the Canaanite woman's plea in verses 20-22.
tips: Notice the phrase 'tradition of the elders' appears in verse 2
Pay attention to Jesus' response about what defiles (verse 11) and the Canaanite woman's faith (verse 22)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (Pharisees and scribes), WHAT (they question Jesus about tradition), WHERE (Jerusalem), and WHY (they want to know about the commandment of God).
tips: Include the issue of hand-washing before eating (verse 2)
Note the commandment about honoring parents (verse 4)
The Canaanite woman's request and Jesus' response (verses 20-22)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Jesus' statement on heart defilement (verse 11), the Canaanite woman's faith (verse 22), or Jesus' response to the tradition (verses 3-4)?
tips: Jesus' declaration that what comes out of the mouth defiles is a powerful reminder of inner purity
The Canaanite woman's response shows faith that transcends ethnic boundaries and is honored by Jesus
The phrase 'crumbs that fall from their masters' illustrates how God's grace is available to all

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Matthew trying to communicate to Jewish believers about the role of tradition and heart purity?
tips: Matthew emphasizes that true worship must come from the heart, not external rituals
The passage shows Jesus' authority over Jewish traditions and His inclusive mission to all nations
The Canaanite woman's story illustrates that God's kingdom is for all people, not just Israel

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The role of tradition in Jewish law, the command about honoring parents, and the response to the Canaanite woman?
tips: In Jewish context, traditions of the elders were rules passed down by the rabbis (e.g., hand-washing before eating)
The tradition of not giving money to parents from a child's inheritance was common, but Jesus says it overrides the commandment of honoring parents
Jesus' response to the Canaanite woman shows that God's kingdom is for all nations, which might challenge Jewish beliefs at the time

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: Jesus says what comes out of the mouth defiles a person. What habit or attitude in your life needs to be addressed for heart purity this week?
tips: Identify one habit that is causing spiritual defilement (e.g., gossip, envy, or pride)
Pray for the strength to change that habit, just as Jesus called for heart purity
Ask God to help you see how your actions are affecting others, like the Canaanite woman's request

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together about this chapter's theme: tradition vs. heart purity
tips: Thank God for revealing the importance of heart purity over external rituals
Ask for the courage to trust God's provision even when traditions seem to be in the way
Pray for the faith of the Canaanite woman to be present in your life

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Matthew 16:13-28 aloud, focusing on Peter's confession and Jesus' response in verses 16-18.
tips: Notice the phrase 'You are the Christ, the Son of the living God' (v.16)
Pay attention to Jesus' blessing 'Blessed are you, Simon Bar-Jonah' (v.17)
Consider the declaration 'on this rock I will build my church' (v.18)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (Jesus and the disciples), WHAT (Peter's confession and Jesus' response), WHERE (Caesarea Philippi), and WHY (to establish the foundation of the church and the necessity of Christ's suffering).
tips: Include Peter's confession of Jesus as the Christ (v.16)
Note Jesus' declaration that Peter is the rock (v.18)
Describe Jesus' prediction of suffering, death, and resurrection (v.21-22)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Peter's confession (v.16), Jesus' blessing (v.17), or the church foundation (v.18).
tips: Peter's confession is a moment of profound divine revelation that Jesus is the Christ, not a human invention
The phrase 'Blessed are you, Simon Bar-Jonah' shows Jesus' recognition of Peter's unique role
The declaration 'on this rock I will build my church' establishes the foundation of the church in Christ's confession

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Matthew trying to communicate to Jewish believers about Jesus being the Christ and the foundation of the church?
tips: Matthew emphasizes that Jesus' identity as the Christ is revealed through God's action (not human wisdom) to Jewish believers
This passage shows that the church is built on the confession of Christ, which is a response to God's revelation
Jesus' prediction of suffering foreshadows the necessity of His death for the church

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The phrase 'Son of the living God', the meaning of 'on this rock', and Jesus' prediction of suffering.
tips: 'Son of the living God' refers to Jesus' divine nature, which Jewish believers might have associated with the dead God of the law
'This rock' in the context refers to Peter's confession (the 'rock' is the confession of faith), not Peter himself
Jesus' prediction of suffering was unexpected for Jewish believers who expected a political Messiah

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply Peter's confession to your life this week? Consider what it means to confess Jesus as the Christ when you face uncertainty.
tips: Identify a situation where you need to confess Jesus as the Christ (the Messiah) rather than relying on your own understanding
Pray for the courage to make that confession in a moment of doubt
Reflect on how your life is built on the rock of Christ's confession

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for revealing Jesus as the Christ through Peter's confession and ask for the courage to build your life on this rock.
tips: Thank God for the revelation of Jesus as the living God (the Christ)
Pray for the strength to confess Jesus as the Christ when it's costly
Ask God to help you build your life on the rock of Christ's confession

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Matthew 17:1-13 aloud, paying attention to the description of Jesus' transfiguration and the voice from the cloud.
tips: Notice the phrase 'his face shone like the sun' (v.2) and 'his clothes became white as light' (v.2) to emphasize divine glory
Pay attention to the dialogue between Moses and Elijah and Jesus (v.3) as a sign of continuity with the Old Testament
Notice the voice from the cloud: 'This is my beloved Son, with whom I am well pleased; listen to him' (v.5) as the divine command

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (Jesus, Peter, James, John, Moses, Elijah) is present, WHAT (Jesus transfigured, Moses and Elijah appear and talk with Jesus, a cloud covers them, and the Father speaks), WHERE (a high mountain), and WHY (to reveal Jesus' divine identity and command the disciples to listen to him).
tips: Include the three disciples (Peter, James, John) who are with Jesus on the mountain
Note the appearance of Moses (Law) and Elijah (Prophets) talking with Jesus
Describe the cloud and the voice from heaven as the divine revelation

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Jesus' transfiguration (v.2), Moses and Elijah talking with Jesus (v.3), or the voice from the cloud (v.5)?
tips: Jesus' transfiguration: His face shining like the sun and clothes white as light reveals his divine glory, which the disciples had not seen before
The presence of Moses and Elijah: This shows the connection between the Law and Prophets and Christ, fulfilling the Jewish expectation
The voice from the cloud: 'This is my beloved Son, with whom I am well pleased; listen to him' is the command that the disciples must obey Jesus

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Matthew trying to communicate to Jewish believers about Jesus' identity and mission through this transfiguration event?
tips: Matthew emphasizes that Jesus is the Son of God who fulfills the Law and Prophets (Moses and Elijah) and must be obeyed
The event shows that the Jewish expectation of the Messiah (who would be the Son of God) is being revealed through Christ
The command to not tell until after the resurrection shows that this event is part of the plan that leads to the resurrection of Jesus

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The appearance of Moses and Elijah, the command about Elijah, or the secrecy of the transfiguration event?
tips: The disciples ask why Elijah must come before the Messiah, but Jesus says John the Baptist (who is the Elijah) has already come, so he is not a future event but a fulfillment of prophecy
The transfiguration reveals Jesus' glory, which the disciples had not seen before, so it is a divine moment that they must understand
The command to not tell anyone until after the resurrection: This was to prevent the disciples from misunderstanding the event as a sign of Jesus' death (which would be confusing for Jewish believers

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: As the voice from the cloud says 'listen to him', what is one area where you can listen to Jesus' guidance this week?
tips: Consider a situation where you have been following your own plans rather than Jesus' guidance
Think about how you can be more attentive to the Holy Spirit's prompting (which is the voice of Christ)
Practice being still and listening to Jesus in your daily life, just as the disciples were commanded to do

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for revealing Jesus' glory and for the command to listen to Him. Ask for courage to obey Him even when it's difficult.
tips: Thank God for showing Jesus' true identity as the Son of God
Ask for the strength to listen to Jesus' guidance in your life and to obey Him
Pray that you would recognize the voice of God (the Holy Spirit) in your decisions

tips: Notice the repetition of 'one flesh' in verse 6
Pay attention to the emotional weight of the rich young ruler's response in verse 20
Note the contrast between the Pharisees' questioning and Jesus' authoritative teaching

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is tested, WHAT Jesus teaches, WHERE this happens, and WHY it matters for Jewish believers.
tips: Include the Pharisees' question about divorce (v1)
Note Jesus' teaching on marriage as a covenant (v3-9)
Describe the rich young ruler's request for eternal life (v12-13) and Jesus' response (v21-22)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Jesus' teaching on marriage (v9), the rich young ruler's response (v20), or the cost of discipleship (v21-22)?
tips: The phrase 'What therefore God has joined together, let not man separate' (v9) shows God's unchangeable design
The rich young ruler's declaration 'All these I have kept' (v20) reveals his deep commitment but also his blindness to true riches
Jesus' command to 'sell what you possess and give to the poor' (v21) highlights the radical nature of discipleship

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Matthew trying to communicate to Jewish believers about marriage, discipleship, and the kingdom of heaven through this passage?
tips: Matthew emphasizes that marriage is a divine covenant that cannot be broken by human will (v9)
He shows that true discipleship requires radical surrender of wealth and self (v21-22)
The inclusion of children (v10) reminds believers of the kingdom's priority

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The Pharisees' question on divorce, the meaning of 'great possessions', or the cost of discipleship?
tips: The phrase 'for any cause' (v1) implies that divorce is allowed in the Mosaic law, but Jesus redefines it as only in cases of adultery (implied by his teaching)
In Jewish context, 'great possessions' (v21) could mean both material wealth and spiritual priorities
The command to 'sell what you possess' is not a literal requirement for all but a metaphor for giving up self-centered wealth

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How does the teaching on the cost of discipleship (v21-22) apply to your life this week?
tips: Consider an area where you hold onto something that is actually a 'possession' that you need to let go for the kingdom
Think about how you can give to the poor or those in need this week, even if it's small
Practice letting go of something that is holding you back from serving God

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray about the cost of discipleship and the design of marriage as revealed in this chapter.
tips: Thank God for His unbreakable design for marriage (v9)
Ask for the courage to give up what is truly valuable for the kingdom
Pray for the grace to see the kingdom of heaven in the humble

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Matthew 21:1-26 aloud, focusing on the crowds' 'Hosanna' (v.9), the temple cleansing (v.12-13), and the stone prophecy (v.42)
tips: Notice the repeated 'Hosanna' (v.9) as a cry of hope for the Messiah
Pay attention to the contrast in v.13: 'house of prayer' vs. 'den of robbers'
The phrase 'the stone that the builders rejected' (v.42) is a key metaphor for Jesus

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: Summarize who (Jesus and disciples), what (the triumphal entry and temple cleansing), where (Bethphage to Jerusalem), and why (to fulfill prophecy and reveal the temple's true purpose)
tips: The disciples preparing the donkey and colt (v.1-11)
Jesus driving out money changers and healing the blind and lame (v.12-15)
The stone that the builders rejected becoming the cornerstone (v.42)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: Which part stood out? Consider: the crowds' 'Hosanna' (v.9), the temple cleansing (v.12-13), or the stone prophecy (v.42)?
tips: The crowds' 'Hosanna' (v.9) shows joyful anticipation of the Messiah
The temple cleansing (v.12-13) reveals Christ's authority as the true temple
The stone prophecy (v.42) emphasizes Jesus as the foundation of God's new community

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Matthew trying to communicate to Jewish believers about Christ's kingdom and identity?
tips: Christ as the humble king who fulfills prophecy (Zech 9:9)
The temple cleansing as a sign of Christ's authority over religious systems
The stone prophecy revealing Christ's role as the cornerstone of God's new covenant

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are confusing? The crowds' 'Hosanna' meaning, the temple cleansing as a sign of authority, or the stone prophecy?
tips: 'Hosanna' (Hebrew: 'hoshia') means 'save' but the crowd's context shows they were not yet aware of the full cost of his kingdom
The temple cleansing was a radical act that would have been seen as a threat to the religious establishment
The stone prophecy (v.42) is a metaphor for Christ being the rejected one who becomes the cornerstone of the new temple

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How does Jesus' entry as the humble king challenge us to be the temple of God in our lives?
tips: Be the temple of God by being a place of healing and prayer (like Jesus healing the blind and lame)
Reject the 'den of robbers' by avoiding selfish practices in our lives
Let Jesus be the cornerstone by trusting him as the foundation of our faith

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray about Jesus as the humble king who cleanses the temple and becomes the cornerstone of God's new community.
tips: Thank God for Jesus as the true temple and the one who heals the broken
Ask for courage to be the temple of God in your community
Pray for the church to be a place of healing and not a den of robbers

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Matthew 22:1-46 aloud, focusing on the wedding feast parable (v. 1-14), the tax question (v. 15-22), and the great commandment (v. 23-46).
tips: Notice the phrase 'kingdom of heaven' appears three times in the parable (v. 1, 11, 12)
Pay attention to the contrast between the king's invitation and the man without a wedding garment (v. 11-13)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: Summarize WHO (Jesus, the king, the invited guests, the Pharisees, the Sadducees), WHAT (Jesus speaks parables and answers questions), WHERE (Jewish context), and WHY (to teach about the kingdom of heaven and the law).
tips: Include the wedding feast parable (v. 1-14) where the king invites guests but one man is without a garment
Note the tax question (v. 15-22) and Jesus' response 'Render to Caesar the things that are Caesar's, and to God the things that are God's'
Describe the great commandment (v. 34-40) where Jesus says love God with all your heart and love your neighbor as yourself

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: Identify 2-3 specific elements from the passage that you find most impactful: the wedding garment, the tax question response, or the two commandments.
tips: The man without a wedding garment (v. 11-13) represents the need for Christ's righteousness to enter the kingdom
The phrase 'render to Caesar' (v. 21) shows Jesus' practical wisdom on handling worldly and spiritual matters
The two commandments (v. 37-38) are the foundation of the law and the heart of Christian living

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Matthew trying to communicate to Jewish believers through this passage?
tips: Matthew's goal was to show that Jesus is the Son for whom the wedding feast is prepared
The parable illustrates that the kingdom of heaven requires righteousness (the garment) that comes through Christ
The two commandments are the summary of the law and the heart of Christian life for Jewish believers

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: Identify 2-3 specific confusing elements in this passage: cultural context, unfamiliar terms, or theological concepts.
tips: The 'wedding garment' symbolizes righteousness that comes from Christ (not self-effort)
The tax question reflects the political tension between Jewish and Roman rule; Jesus' answer shows that one can honor both God and Caesar without compromise
The two commandments are the foundation of the law and the gospel, not a simplification of the law

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the concept of being clothed in Christ's righteousness (the wedding garment) to your daily life this week?
tips: Consider one area where you feel unrighteous (like the man without the garment) and ask how Christ's righteousness can cover it
Pray for the Holy Spirit to help you live by the two commandments (love God and love neighbor) in your relationships
Do one small act of love for a neighbor this week, as Jesus taught

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together about this chapter's theme: the wedding feast and the two commandments.
tips: Thank God for the wedding feast of His kingdom that we enter through Christ
Pray for the strength to be clothed in Christ's righteousness
Ask God to help you love Him and your neighbor as Jesus did

chapters.chapterTitle: Woes to the Scribes and Pharisees

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Matthew 23:1-35 aloud, paying attention to the repetition of 'woe' (three times) and the phrase 'blind guides'.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'woe to you, scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites!' (three times)
Pay attention to the phrase 'blind guides' and the imagery of 'serpents and brood of vipers'
The emotional tone shifts from condemnation to lament over Jerusalem (v. 37)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (the scribes and Pharisees) does WHAT (teaches the law but hypocritically), WHERE (in the Jewish religious community), and WHY (to avoid the weightier matters of the law).
tips: Include the seven woes and the criticism of heavy burdens (v. 4)
Note the hypocrisy in making proselytes for show (v. 10)
Describe the neglect of justice, mercy, and faithfulness (v. 23)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the heavy burdens (v. 4), the proselyte example (v. 10), or the tithe example (v. 23).
tips: The heavy burdens: 'they tie up heavy burdens, hard to bear' shows the burden of empty rituals
The proselyte example: they travel far to make one proselyte but then make him 'twice as much a child of hell' - a shocking contrast
The tithe example: they neglect the weightier matters (justice, mercy, faithfulness) in favor of minor things (mint, dill, cumin)

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Matthew trying to communicate to Jewish believers about the scribes and Pharisees through this passage?
tips: Christ exposes the hypocrisy of religious leaders who teach but do not practice the weightier matters of the law
The passage calls for a return to justice, mercy, and faithfulness rather than empty rituals
It also laments Jerusalem's rejection of Christ (v. 37) as a consequence of the same hypocrisy

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The phrase 'child of hell' (v. 15), the comparison to 'serpents' (v. 33), or Christ's weeping over Jerusalem (v. 37)?
tips: 'Child of hell' is a metaphor for being more separated from God than the scribes and Pharisees (who are already in spiritual death)
'Serpents and brood of vipers' are strong imagery for deceit and unrighteousness, common in Jewish apocalyptic literature
Christ's weeping over Jerusalem is a prediction of its destruction but also a call for repentance (as in the Gospels)

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: This week, identify one area where you are focusing on the minor things (like rituals) but neglecting justice and mercy in your relationships with others.
tips: Consider an area where you're holding back from practicing justice and mercy
Think about how you can 'do the weightier matters' in your daily life
Pray for the courage to prioritize mercy and justice over empty rituals

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for exposing the hypocrisy of religious leaders and ask for courage to prioritize justice and mercy.
tips: Thank God for the truth that Christ is the light of the world and not the scribes and Pharisees
Pray for the church to avoid the scribes and Pharisees' mistakes
Ask God to help you see the weightier matters in your daily life

chapters.chapterTitle: Signs of the End of the Age

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Matthew 24:1-45 aloud, focusing on the dialogue between Jesus and his disciples in verses 3-45.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'many will come in my name' (v. 11)
Pay attention to the phrase 'abomination of desolation' (v. 15) and the call to flee (v. 16)
Notice the contrast between the current temple destruction and the coming of the Son of Man (v. 30)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO Jesus is speaking to, WHAT he prophesies, WHERE and WHEN it will happen, and WHY he gives these signs.
tips: Include the disciples' question about the sign of the end (v. 3)
Note the destruction of the temple (v. 2) and the coming of the Son of Man (v. 30)
Describe the universal spread of the gospel before the end (v. 14)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the warning about false prophets (v. 11), the sign of the Son of Man (v. 30), or the call to flee (v. 16)?
tips: The warning about false prophets: 'many will come in my name' shows the danger of deception
The phrase 'abomination of desolation' (v. 15) is a direct reference to Daniel 9:27 and the desecration of the temple
The call to flee (v. 16) is a practical command for immediate action in the face of impending disaster

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Matthew trying to communicate to Jewish believers about the end times and Jesus' return?
tips: The gospel will be preached to all nations before the end (v. 14)
Jewish believers were to recognize the signs of the end and be ready for Christ's return
The destruction of the temple (v. 2) was a sign of the coming end for the Jewish people

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The meaning of the 'abomination of desolation', the timing of the end, or the 'sign of the Son of Man'?
tips: The 'abomination of desolation' (v. 15) refers to the desecration of the temple by the Roman military, as in Daniel 9:27
The phrase 'no one knows the day or hour' (v. 36) emphasizes that the end is not predictable by human calculation
The 'sign of the Son of Man' (v. 30) is a heavenly sign that precedes the end, but the exact timing is unknown

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the call to 'stay awake' (v. 42) in your daily life this week?
tips: Set a specific time each day to check in on your spiritual readiness
Share the gospel message with one person this week to embody the universal spread (v. 14)
Pray for the courage to flee from false teachings (v. 11) when you encounter them

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God that He provides the end times with the gospel to all nations. Ask for the courage to stay awake and be ready for Christ's return.
tips: Thank God for His promise to provide the end times with the gospel to all nations
Ask for discernment to recognize false prophets and the signs of the end
Pray for the courage to flee from danger when the abomination of desolation appears

chapters.chapterTitle: The Plot, the Supper, and Gethsemane

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Matthew 26:1-46 aloud, paying attention to the emotional tone of the anointing (v.6-7), the Last Supper (v.26-28), and the Gethsemane prayer (v.39).
tips: Notice the woman's 'very expensive ointment' (v.6) and how it foreshadows burial
Pay attention to the repeated phrase 'this is my body/blood' in the Last Supper (v.26,28)
Listen for the depth of Jesus' sorrow in Gethsemane: 'My Father, if it be possible...' (v.39)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: Summarize who is involved, what they do, where it happens, and why (the purpose) in Matthew 26:1-46.
tips: Include the anointing at Bethany (v.6-7)
Note the Last Supper where Jesus institutes the Lord's Supper (v.26-28)
Describe Jesus' prayer in Gethsemane (v.36-46)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the anointing (v.6-7), the Last Supper (v.26-28), or the Gethsemane prayer (v.39)?
tips: The anointing: a woman using expensive ointment to prepare Jesus for burial
The Last Supper: Jesus' declaration of the new covenant through His body and blood
The Gethsemane prayer: Jesus' submission to God's will despite the cost

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Matthew trying to communicate to Jewish believers about Jesus' death and the new covenant through this passage?
tips: Matthew emphasizes Jesus' fulfillment of the Law and the new covenant
The passage shows Jesus' authority and the necessity of His death for the forgiveness of sins
This passage bridges Jewish understanding of the Passover with the new covenant

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are confusing? The anointing, the Last Supper, or the Gethsemane prayer?
tips: Why did the woman anoint Jesus at Bethany? (It was a practice for burial, but Jesus was not yet dying)
What does 'the cup' represent? (It refers to the suffering and death of Jesus, the cup of God's wrath)
How does Jesus' submission in Gethsemane (v.39) show His complete obedience?

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of the Last Supper (the blood of the covenant) in your life this week?
tips: Consider a situation where you need to be a 'living sacrifice' like Jesus
Think about how the blood of Christ covers your sins and how you can live in that freedom
Pray for the courage to follow Jesus' example in obedience

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray specifically about the theme of Jesus' submission in Gethsemane and the new covenant.
tips: Thank God for Jesus' sacrifice and the blood of the covenant
Ask for the strength to submit to God's will when it's hard
Pray for a heart that understands the cost of discipleship

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Matthew 27:1-54 aloud, focusing on the dialogue between Jesus and Pilate in verses 11-12 and the crowd's reaction in verses 22-23.
tips: Notice the phrase 'you have said so' in verse 11, which shows Jesus' submission to Pilate's question
Pay attention to the crowd's unified cry for crucifixion (verse 22-23) and the emotional weight of their decision
The tearing of the temple curtain in verse 51 is a dramatic climax that signifies God's new access through Christ

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is involved, WHAT happens, WHERE it takes place, and WHY (the purpose or cause).
tips: Include the role of Judas in betraying Jesus and returning the thirty pieces of silver (v.3-5)
Note Pilate's question about Jesus being the King of the Jews (v.11) and the crowd's response
Describe the crucifixion and the tearing of the temple curtain (v.51)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Jesus' submission to Pilate (v.11), the crowd's demand for crucifixion (v.22-23), or the tearing of the temple curtain (v.51).
tips: Jesus' submission in 'You have said so' (v.11) shows his divine authority without resistance
The crowd's unified cry for crucifixion (v.22-23) reveals the people's role in Jesus' death
The tearing of the temple curtain (v.51) is a powerful symbol of God's new access through Christ

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Matthew trying to communicate to Jewish believers through this passage?
tips: Matthew emphasizes that Jesus, the Jewish Messiah, is crucified for the sins of the world (v.27-28)
The temple curtain tearing (v.51) shows that God now offers direct access to the Holy Spirit through Christ
This passage fulfills Jewish prophecies about the Messiah's suffering and death

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: Identify 2-3 specific confusing elements in this passage and provide brief clarifications.
tips: The Jewish authorities condemned Jesus because they saw him as a threat to their religious order (v.1-2)
The thirty pieces of silver were the price of a slave in the Roman system (v.3-5) - but Judas returned it because he was ashamed of his betrayal
The temple curtain tearing (v.51) signifies that the barrier between God and humanity is removed through Christ's death

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can this passage impact your life this week?
tips: This week, pray for the courage to let go of the 'temple curtain' that keeps you from God (e.g., guilt, fear, sin) and seek His presence
Reflect on how the crowd's demand for crucifixion (v.22-23) mirrors your own decisions to follow Christ
Practice daily confession and forgiveness as a step toward the new access in Christ

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray specifically about the theme of this passage.
tips: Thank God that through Christ's death, we have access to Him (v.51)
Ask for the strength to face the 'crowd' that demands our crucifixion when we are called to follow Christ
Pray for the courage to let go of the thirty pieces of silver (the things we value more than Christ)

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Matthew 28:1-20 aloud, focusing on the angel's declaration and Jesus' commission.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'he has risen' (v.6) shows the certainty of resurrection
Pay attention to the emotional shift from fear to joy as the women run to tell the disciples (v.8)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (the women, Jesus, disciples) is tested, WHAT (the resurrection and commission) happens, WHERE (the tomb and Galilee), and WHY (to empower disciples with authority and mission).
tips: Include the earthquake and angel's appearance at the tomb (v.3-7)
Note the women's fear and joy as they run to the disciples (v.8-10)
Describe Jesus' commission to make disciples of all nations (v.18-20)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the angel's declaration of resurrection (v.6), Jesus meeting the women (v.9-10), or the Great Commission (v.18-20)?
tips: The angel's declaration 'He is not here, for he has risen' (v.6) brings certainty to the women
Jesus' greeting 'Greetings!' (v.9) shows intimate relationship with his followers
The Great Commission (v.18-20) is the most significant because it calls the disciples to the world

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Matthew trying to communicate to Jewish believers about the resurrection and the mission of Jesus?
tips: Matthew emphasizes that Jesus has all authority (v.18) to reassure Jewish believers of his identity
The Great Commission is given to the disciples to extend the church beyond Jewish circles
The promise 'I am with you always' (v.20) addresses the fear of the disciples being abandoned by God

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging for Jewish believers? The resurrection, the commission to all nations, and the promise of presence?
tips: The resurrection: Jewish believers expected a physical resurrection of the Messiah as a king, but here Jesus is risen as the living Lord
The commission to 'all nations' (v.19) may seem beyond the Jewish context of the time
The promise 'I am with you always' (v.20) addresses the fear of the disciples being abandoned by God

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you take action this week to be a part of the Great Commission?
tips: Share the gospel with someone who is struggling (like the women did)
Pray for the courage to be a disciple-maker in your community
Join a small group or volunteer to help others in your area

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for the resurrection and ask for the strength to live out the Great Commission.
tips: Thank God that Jesus has risen and is now the living Lord
Pray for the courage to share the gospel with others
Ask God to help you be a disciple-maker in your daily life
